[$14 at Amazon](https://assoc-redirect.amazon.com/g/r/https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0014D2GEK?tag=cnet-api-20&linkCode=ogi&th=1&psc=1) at Amazon](https://assoc-redirect.amazon.com/g/r/https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00OJOL3KO?tag=cnet-api-20&linkCode=ogi&th=1&psc=1) If you're finding yourself extra tired recently, yearning for that next vacation, you aren't alone. One survey cited by the National Safety Council found that [3 out of 5 adults](https://www.safetyandhealthmagazine.com/articles/22112-exhausted-nation-americans-more-tired-than-ever-survey-finds) in the US reported feeling more tired during the pandemic due to disrupted routines, long working hours and endless video meetings. This tiredness may still persist. Extreme fatigue can be caused by a multitude of issues like being overworked, lack of sleep or not eating balanced meals. However, if you're constantly fatigued throughout the day or have noticed shortness of breath, pale or yellowish skin, mental fog, muscle weakness or personality changes, you may have a [vitamin B deficiency](https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/vitamin-deficiency-anemia/symptoms-causes/syc-20355025). B vitamins are vital for our energy throughout the day and are often included in energy supplements. Whether you suspect you may have a vitamin B deficiency, aren't getting [enough B vitamins in your diet](/health/nutrition/beyond-vitamin-c-eat-these-foods-for-a-healthy-immune-system/) or are missing other essential energy vitamins, an added supplement might be right for you. Here's what you need to know. Vitamins and nutrients that boost energy In addition to coffee, tea or energy drinks, certain vitamins that can help boost energy. These natural vitamins include but aren't limited to: [Vitamin Bs](https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/vitamins/vitamin-b/): biotin, folate and B12) are responsible for helping the body process energy from food. [Vitamin C](https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/vitamin-c/): Aids in [energy production in the mitochondria](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7019700/)of our cells. [Magnesium](https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/magnesium/): Aids in the [production and use of energy molecules](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7019700/), or ATP. [Iron](https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/iron/): Essential in the production of hemoglobin and transportation of oxygen. If your diet lacks these vitamins and you are experiencing fatigue, you may benefit from an added supplement. Always consult a doctor before adding any supplements to your diet. Is it better to take B12 or B complex? B12 and B complex are both very important. However, with B12 supplements, you are only getting one B vitamin, and with B complex supplements, you are intaking all eight B vitamins. If you lack B vitamins from your diet, consider a B complex vitamin. If you are [B12 deficient](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/vitamin-b12-deficiency-anemia), a B12 supplement may be better for you. Does B12 give you energy right away? As much as we wish this were true, it is not. Taking a B12 supplement or any vitamin B supplement will not give you energy right away like a cup of coffee. Instead, it could take a [few weeks](https://www.nhs.uk/medicines/cyanocobalamin/) of taking B12 regularly until it increases your energy levels.
